description: Aerospace & Defense vertical brain seed data for Atlas GTM

brain.name: Aerospace & Defense Brain
brain.description: Knowledge base for defense & aerospace technology targeting government contractors, defense tech startups, and aerospace manufacturers

icp_rules.name: Government Contractor Status
icp_rules.criteria: Company is a registered government contractor with active federal contracts or pursuing federal opportunities
icp_rules.tier_impact: Tier 1 if active contracts, Tier 2 if pursuing

icp_rules.name: Security Clearance Capability
icp_rules.criteria: Company has facility clearance (FCL) or employees with security clearances at Secret level or above

icp_rules.name: Defense Industry Vertical
icp_rules.criteria: Company operates in defense-adjacent industry (aerospace, defense, cybersecurity, intelligence, space)

icp_rules.name: CMMC Compliance Status
icp_rules.criteria: Company is pursuing or has achieved CMMC certification (Level 2+)
icp_rules.tier_impact: Active compliance work indicates serious DIB participation

icp_rules.name: Decision Maker Title
icp_rules.criteria: Contact holds decision-making authority for contracts, programs, or technology adoption

icp_rules.name: Company Size - DIB Sweet Spot
icp_rules.criteria: Company size is within target range for mid-market defense contractors (50-5000 employees)

icp_rules.name: Revenue Scale
icp_rules.criteria: Company has sufficient revenue to invest in solutions ($10M-$500M range)

icp_rules.name: Prime vs Subcontractor
icp_rules.criteria: Company acts as prime contractor on federal contracts (vs. only subcontractor)
icp_rules.tier_impact: Primes have more complex compliance needs

icp_rules.name: Geographic Location
icp_rules.criteria: Company located in defense hub (DC metro, San Diego, Huntsville, Colorado Springs, etc.)

icp_rules.name: Recent Funding or Growth
icp_rules.criteria: Company has raised funding recently or showing growth indicators
icp_rules.tier_impact: Growing companies more likely to invest

response_templates.name: Interested Follow-up
response_templates.template:
Hi {{first_name}},

Thank you for your interest in {{product_name}}. I'd love to learn more about {{company_name}}'s current challenges with {{pain_point}}.

Given your work in the defense space, I imagine compliance and security are top priorities. Would you have 20 minutes this week for a quick call? I can share some specific examples of how we've helped similar defense contractors.

Best,
{{sender_name}}

response_templates.name: Interested Follow-up - Direct
Meeting Confirmation
response_templates.template:
Hi {{first_name}},

Great! I've sent over a calendar invite for {{meeting_time}}. Looking forward to discussing how we can help {{company_name}}.

To make our time productive, I'll prepare some specific insights relevant to {{company_vertical}} contractors. Feel free to bring any questions about {{specific_topic}}.

In the meantime, here's a brief overview of our work with {{reference_customer}} - similar situation to yours.

Best,
{{sender_name}}

response_templates.name: Question Response - Compliance
response_templates.template:
Hi {{first_name}},

Great question about {{compliance_topic}}.

{{compliance_answer}}

This is an area we've helped many defense contractors navigate. Given the CMMC deadlines and increasing scrutiny, it's a common concern.

Would it be helpful to schedule a quick call to dive deeper? I can also connect you with our compliance team if that would be useful.

Best,
{{sender_name}}

response_templates.name: Question Response - Technical
response_templates.template:
Hi {{first_name}},

Thanks for the technical question about {{technical_topic}}.

{{technical_answer}}

I'd be happy to have our technical team provide more details. We've implemented this for several contractors handling {{classification_level}} work.

Would a brief technical deep-dive be valuable? I can arrange a call with one of our solutions architects.

Best,
{{sender_name}}

response_templates.name: Objection Handler - Generic
Not Interested - Soft Touch
response_templates.template:
Hi {{first_name}},

I appreciate you letting me know. Timing is everything in this industry, and I completely understand.

If it's helpful, I'd be happy to share some non-sales resources on {{relevant_topic}} that might be valuable regardless - we've compiled some insights from working with 50+ defense contractors.

No pressure, but feel free to reach out if circumstances change. I'll keep an eye on {{company_name}}'s work and reach out if I see something specifically relevant.

Best,
{{sender_name}}

response_templates.name: Referral Request
response_templates.template:
Hi {{first_name}},

Thank you for the introduction to {{referral_name}}. I really appreciate you thinking of us.

I'll reach out to them with context about our conversation. Is there anything specific you think I should mention or avoid when connecting with them?

Also, if there's ever anything I can do to help {{company_name}} or return the favor, please don't hesitate to ask.

Best,
{{sender_name}}

objection_handlers.objection: We already have a solution in place
objection_handlers.response: That's great that you have something in place. Many of our customers came to us with existing solutions but found they needed something more specialized for government/defense requirements. We often complement existing tools rather than replace them entirely - especially when it comes to compliance controls and audit trails. Would it be helpful to understand where we typically add value alongside existing solutions?

objection_handlers.objection: We don't have the budget right now
objection_handlers.response: I completely understand budget constraints, especially with contract cycles and continuing resolutions. Many defense contractors actually find that our solution reduces overall costs by 30-40% through automation and compliance streamlining. We also offer flexible pricing aligned with contract award cycles and can structure deals around IDIQ task orders. Would it make sense to at least understand the potential ROI for a future budget cycle?

objection_handlers.objection: We need to focus on our current contracts
objection_handlers.response: Absolutely - execution on current contracts is priority one. That's actually where we help most. Our solution is designed to reduce the operational burden on existing programs while improving compliance posture for audits. Many customers tell us it actually freed up capacity they didn't know they had, which helped them win additional work. Would a 15-minute overview be worth your time to see if this could help with current program execution?

objection_handlers.objection: I need to check with our security/compliance team
objection_handlers.response: That's exactly the right approach for any new tool in the defense space - security review is non-negotiable. We're fully FedRAMP authorized (Moderate baseline), have ATOs with several major agencies, and maintain SOC 2 Type II certification. I can provide our complete security documentation package including penetration test results and even arrange a direct conversation between our security team and yours. Would that be helpful?

objection_handlers.objection: The decision isn't mine to make
objection_handlers.response: I appreciate you being upfront about that. In the defense space, buying decisions often involve multiple stakeholders - programs, contracts, security, and IT. Would it be helpful if I prepared some materials specifically for the decision maker? I can tailor them to address their likely concerns - whether that's ROI for the CFO, compliance for the FSO, or technical fit for the CTO. Also, would you be open to including them in a brief call?

Contract awards are always the critical dependency. Many of our customers actually start the evaluation process before award so they can move quickly once the contract is in place - especially for IDIQ vehicles where you need to be ready to respond to task orders. We can structure our engagement to align with your award timeline. When are you expecting the decision?

objection_handlers.objection: We've had bad experiences with vendors
objection_handlers.response: I hear that a lot in the defense space - the vendor landscape can be challenging. Without knowing specifics, I can tell you our approach is different: we focus exclusively on defense contractors, all our customer success team has cleared backgrounds, and we offer pilot programs so you can validate before committing. What specifically went wrong before? Understanding that would help me explain how we've addressed those issues.

objection_handlers.objection: Our prime requires us to use specific tools
objection_handlers.response: Prime flowdown requirements are real constraints. We work with many subs in that situation. A few things to consider: we often integrate with prime-mandated systems rather than replace them, some of our capabilities address compliance requirements that primes actually prefer, and we can help you document compliance for prime audits. Which prime are you working under? We may already have integration experience with their stack.

Company size is less important than the compliance requirements you face. We work with contractors ranging from 20 to 5,000 employees. For smaller teams, our solution is often even more valuable because you don't have dedicated compliance staff. We have a tier specifically designed for emerging contractors that scales with your contract volume. Would it help to see how we've helped other small businesses in the DIB?

objection_handlers.objection: Our IT team will build something internally
objection_handlers.response: Build vs. buy is always a consideration. A few things to think about: maintaining compliance documentation and keeping up with CMMC/NIST updates is ongoing work that diverts your team from core mission. We've seen internal builds cost 3-5x more over 3 years when you factor in maintenance and opportunity cost. That said, if you do build internally, we'd love to stay in touch - many companies circle back to us after realizing the maintenance burden.

market_research.content: The FY2025 defense budget request is $895 billion, with significant increases in cybersecurity, space, and AI/ML programs. Key growth areas include: cyber operations (+18% YoY), space systems (+15% YoY), autonomous systems (+22% YoY), and AI/ML applications (+25% YoY). The DIB is seeing consolidation among mid-market contractors while VC-backed defense tech startups continue aggressive expansion.
market_research.source: Congressional Budget Office / DoD Budget Justification

market_research.content: CMMC 2.0 is now in full effect with Level 2 certification required for all CUI-handling contractors. Approximately 85,000 companies in the DIB need certification. C3PAO assessment capacity remains constrained with average wait times of 4-6 months. Companies without CMMC certification are being excluded from new contract opportunities. Self-assessment option remains for Level 1 only.

Defense tech VC funding reached $9.2B in 2024, up 35% from 2023. Key sectors: autonomous systems (28%), cybersecurity (22%), space tech (20%), AI/ML for defense (18%), and advanced manufacturing (12%). Notable trend: traditional Silicon Valley VCs and sovereign wealth funds significantly increasing defense tech allocations. Top funded companies include Shield AI, Anduril, Rebellion Defense, and Epirus.

Top challenges reported by defense contractors: 1) CMMC compliance burden (78% cite as major challenge), 2) Talent acquisition with clearances (72%), 3) Cash flow management around contract cycles (58%), 4) Supply chain security requirements (55%), 5) Cybersecurity incident reporting requirements (52%), 6) SBIR/STTR commercialization gap (48%).

DoD is accelerating acquisition timelines through multiple initiatives: Other Transaction Authority (OTA) usage up 40% YoY, Middle Tier Acquisition pathways expanding, and Commercial Solutions Opening (CSO) becoming standard for innovation adoption. Software acquisition pathway requires continuous ATO and DevSecOps practices. These changes favor agile companies but increase compliance complexity.

The defense industry faces a critical shortage of cleared personnel. Backlog for Secret clearances averages 150 days, TS/SCI averages 450 days. This bottleneck affects hiring for 65% of defense contractors. Solutions include Trusted Workforce 2.0 adoption, continuous vetting, and remote work policies for unclassified portions of work. Companies investing in training pipelines see competitive advantage.

New supply chain security requirements under Section 889 and DFARS 252.204-7012 are expanding. Contractors must now track and report on supplier cybersecurity posture. Software Bill of Materials (SBOM) requirements are becoming standard for software-intensive programs. Third-party risk management is now a contract requirement for most primes.

DoD AI adoption accelerating under CDAO leadership. Responsible AI principles are now mandatory for all AI-enabled systems. Key application areas: predictive maintenance (45% adoption), intelligence analysis (38%), autonomous systems (32%), cybersecurity (30%), and logistics optimization (28%). Challenge: AI systems must meet rigorous T&E requirements before deployment.
